Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Medium: Collaborative Research: Crafting a Human-Centric Environment to Support Human Health Needs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers and providers alike are recognizing that human-centric smart environments can provide health monitoring services and support aging in place through adaptive interventions. The need for the development of such technologies is underscored by the aging of the population, the cost of formal health care, and the importance that individuals place on remaining independent in their own homes. The goal of this project is to design, implement, and evaluate in-home techniques for generating reports of activities and social interactions that are useful for monitoring well being and for automating intervention strategies for persons with dementia. The plan is to design machine learning techniques that make effective use of sensor data to perform automated activity monitoring and prompting-based interventions that are beneficial for the residents as well as for their caregivers and family. The environment is human-centric because it learns information about its human residents and uses this information to provide activity-aware monitoring and intervention services. By transforming everyday environments into smart environments, many older adults with cognitive and physical impairment can lead independent lives in their own homes. A key component of this project is an evaluation of the technologies in actual homes with volunteer older adults and thus will assess the technologies for acceptance with the target population.

This project addresses NSF?s Smart Health and Wellbeing goal of leveraging computational expertise leading to fundamental advances in the development of algorithms to create improvements in safe, effective, and patient-centered health and wellness services. The development of a Gerontechnology class is focused on training students to design and use these technologies. This effort includes REU and IGERT students in the research project, which involves students from underrepresented groups in this multidisciplinary, collaborative effort. To facility community-wide use, comparison and collaboration, all of our datasets, tools, and course materials will be disseminated from our project web page.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to provide human-centric smart environment technologies that perform automated health assessment and intervention. The long-term objective of the research is to improve human health and impact health care delivery by developing smart environments that aid with health monitoring, assessment, and intervention.

Intellectual Merit: In this project we move closer to our long-term objective by designing, implementing, and evaluating in-home techniques for detecting and recognizing activities that are useful for monitoring well being and for automating intervention strategies for persons with dementia. Specifically, we installed over 50 smart homes with older adult residents. We design activity discovery and recognition algorithms that identify activities in these settings in real time as residents perform the activities. We validate the algorithms based on expert-labeled data as well as resident feedback.

The learned activities provide a vocabulary for expressing human behavior that we then use to assess cognitive health changes over time. Our algorithms predict clinical diagnoses and clinical test scores using longitudinal behavior data. Finally, we design activity forecasting algorithms that are used as the basis for an an activity prompting intervention. The health intervention is also tested in smart homes with older adult residents.

Broader Impact: The research we performed in this project addresses NSF's Smart Health and Wellbeing goal of leveraging computational expertise to create improvements in safe, effective, and patient-centered health and wellness services. This contribution is significant because it will allow adults with cognitive and physical limitations to live in their homes longer, thereby benefiting both health-care quality and cost of care to society.

To further the impact of this project we designed a Gerontechnology class that trained students from multiple disciplines to utilize these technologies. The class has been offered to undergraduate and graduate students in Psychology, Sociology, and Nursing, as well as to students in Computer Science, Chemical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering and Bioengineering. In addition, the investigators led a tutorial on Gerontechnology techniques to train members of the community in this research area. To facility community-wide use, comparison and collaboration, all of our datasets, tools, and course materials are disseminated from our project web page.
